Introduction

Controlled Drugs (CDs) are subject to special legal controls under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971 and Misuse of Drugs Regulations 2001 and 2013 (as amended); because there is a potential for them to be misused or diverted, causing possible harm. The Health Acts (2006 & 2013) set in place a framework for strengthening governance and monitoring arrangements for CDs.
This policy gives an overview of English law and good practice relating to Controlled Drugs in hospitals, providing the required standard operating procedures for practice.
The 2001 Regulations set out a number of schedules, which classify Controlled Drugs (CDs) according to different levels of control. These are explained in this policy.
The Controlled Drug Accountable Officer can authorise the enhancement of controls to a CD preparation or any other medicine applied in the Trust.

Enhancements of controls, above the legal requirement, which are permanent are outlined in this policy, though may also be implemented on temporary basis in all or specified units at any time. All extra controls are where it is considered that this will reduce the risk of diversion of medicines and improve the audit trail of the supply and administration of that medicine.

Controlled Drugs in Schedule 2 have ‘CD POM' printed on the original packaging. All repackaged Schedule 2 CD containers dispensed from pharmacy have ‘Store in a Controlled Drug Cupboard' on the dispensing label. CD preparations are marked in the British National Formulary (BNF) with the symbol ‘CD'.

The Controlled Drug Accountable Officer has the legal authority for Controlled Drug management in the Trust and under no circumstances can any clinical areas unilaterally make changes to any Controlled Drug systems or procedures.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Ensure the Trust complies with the legal requirements of the Misuse of Drugs Regulations (1971), all other relevant Controlled Drugs Legislation, national best practice recommendations from the Royal Pharmaceutical Society and NHS Guidance, including Patient Safety Alerts.
Seek to provide clear standards, robust systems and procedures to manage the risk posed by Controlled Drugs for all staff to follow.

In doing so, adherence to this document will ensure that no patient, staff member or visitor is put at risk as a result of incorrect handing of controlled drugs; and the diversion of controlled drugs for illegal purposes is minimised.
Definitions

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Site and Host Risk and Compliance Group, or equivalent
Receiving and noting or actioning exceptions raised by HMOC (or equivalent) concerning controlled drugs.
MSE Hospitals Medicines Optimisation Committee (HMOC), or equivalent
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalate concerns to the Chief Nurse or Site Director of Nursing or Medical Director as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the Host Risk & Compliance Group or Patient Safety Group (if needed) on developments, concerns and progress concerning the safe use of controlled drugs.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG), or equivalent
Reporting controlled drug auditing;

Identifying, developing and promoting best practice for controlled drugs. This will include supporting the implementation of external legislation and guidance from UK Law, NHS England, CQC, NICE and other organisations;
Coordinating and providing support for process and system changes to reduce the likelihood of non-compliance and medication errors occurring and recurring;
Reporting into MSE Hospitals Medicines Optimisation Committee and at site level the risk and compliance group (or patient safety group) as appropriate for the subject material.
Site Clinical Directorate Governance Groups
Reviewing audit data and taking action with respect to service delivery for their care areas;
Ensuring attendance and engagement at the site Medication Optimisation and Safety Group;
Ensuring involvement of the site pharmacy operations manager and Medication Safety Team in controlled drugs issues, including planned refurbishment works.
Pharmacy Directorate Governance
Safe, effective and secure supply of all medicines to all sites.
Ensuring the undertaking, communication of and supporting clinical areas in response to audits of controlled drugs and AdioS monitoring.
Management of Controlled Drugs held in the Pharmacy, their monitoring, preparation into ready to use presentations and the safe and secure supply to wards and departments.
Chief Executive
Ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Appointing a CD Accountable Officer and providing them with adequate resources to enable them to carry out the role.
Controlled Drugs Accountable Officer (CDAO)

4.7.1 A senior officer within the Trust, who has a statutory duty under the Controlled Drugs (Supervision of Management and Use) Regulations 2006, to ensure the safe and effective use and management of all CDs prescribed, dispensed, supplied and administered in accordance with services provided and functions of the trust.

Ensuring that the Care Quality Commission is notified upon appointment to the role, as required by law. They should also ensure that they inform the chair of the CD local intelligence network (CDLIN).
Ensuring that they are not be routinely involved in the prescribing supply or administration of CDs but are familiar with CDs their actions and uses.
Ensuring that the Trust operates appropriate arrangements for the safe, secure and effective management of controlled drugs within the Trust; including destruction and disposal.
Ensuring standard operating procedures are in place, implemented and regularly reviewed and updated, as described in this policy and within the site pharmacy departments.
Ensuring processes in place are appropriately monitored, audited and learning from practice happens.
Ensuring training is in place for individuals working with CDs and that this is appropriate.

Ensuring that an effective route is in place for reporting concerns or complaints and those adequate records are maintained in this regard. They ensure the system in place demonstrates that appropriate assessment, investigation and actions are undertaken. This will include liaison with the Trust LSMS for investigations, as required.
There is effective sharing of information regarding the management and use of CDs including sharing of information between organisations, regulators and agencies, including CDLIN.
4.7.2 Some aspects of this role are delegated as detailed below. However the responsibility cannot be delegated.
Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the Site Directors of Nursing that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated CD issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Director of Nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated CD issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Chief Medical Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the Site Medical Directors that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated CD issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Medical Director
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated CD issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Pharmacy Head of Department
Ensure systems established are operating on their sites effectively and appropriately;
Deputise for the CDAO in their absence;
Ensuring security of the premises licensed on site under the Home Office Controlled Drugs Licence;
Working with the LSMS to assist in any investigation as required.
Site Pharmacy Operations Manager
Managing the day-to-day management of controlled drugs across the site in accordance with standard operating procedures;
Co-ordinating the on-going review of all standard operating procedures, with site counterparts, pertaining to CDs ensuring they remain appropriate and up-to-date;
Ensuring medication errors involving CDs within pharmacy are reported, investigated and actioned appropriately, maintaining a clear record using incident reporting systems;
Ensuring that audits are undertaken by the site pharmacy staff in a timely way.

Monitoring and Reporting key trends in the supply and use of Controlled Drugs, including the regular monitoring of ADiOS (Abusable Drugs Investigational Software) the results of which are downloaded monthly;
Ensuring all staff within pharmacy are suitably trained in accordance with pharmacy standard operating procedures.
Medication Safety & Governance Team (pharmacy)
Managing the Controlled Drug Audit programme.
Monitoring all medication incidents pertaining to Controlled Drugs and providing information to the CDAO in the appropriate format;
Participating in the provision of materials for training and reference purposes for all relevant staff.
Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS)
Working with the CDAO for investigations as required by the statutory instrument 2006 No 3148 of CD (supervision of management and use) regulations 2006.
Heads of Nursing/ Midwifery and Matrons
Ensuring Ward/department managers are implementing and monitoring controlled drugs management in their areas;
Ensuring areas under their responsibility are appropriately monitored and supported following audit to ensure sustained improvement is achieved;
Reporting medication errors and near miss incidents involving CDs using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
Accountable Individual (i.e. Registered Nurse/Midwife in charge of a care area often known as ward manager, senior staff nurse)
Ensuring the safe, secure and appropriate management of CDs is maintained in their clinical area;
Being aware of their legal responsibilities such as delegating control of access to CDs (i.e. key-holding, ordering etc.);
Ensuring that ward/dept. staff know and comply with Trust policy. In doing so ensuring relevant training has been completed;
Ensuring adequate dissemination and implementation of policies and procedures, including the completion of actions identified from the CD Audit in a timely manner;
Reporting medication errors and near miss incidents involving CDs using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.

Authorised person (i.e. registered nurse/midwife in charge or another registrant authorised by the registered nurse/midwife in charge as a delegate. This can include ODPs, and authorised radiographers for example)
Ensuring the safe and appropriate management of controlled drugs they are involved with;
Ensuring relevant training has been completed as requested, and as such have the relevant competencies;
Working within current legislation and within the code of conduct of their professional body;
Providing direct supervision of all student nurses/midwives in the undertaking of their training;
Reporting medication errors and near miss incidents involving CDs using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy;
Only undertaking responsibilities that have been authorised by the accountable individual (in agreement with the CDAO).
Prescriber

All prescribers involved in the prescribing of Controlled Drugs must comply with the requirements of the policy and ensure all prescriptions / written orders on inpatient charts are written in accordance with the law;
Reporting medication errors and near miss incidents involving CDs using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy
Pharmacy Staff
Ensuring CDs are stored and distributed in accordance with the law;
Making proper legal records of all transactions (including destruction) and retaining these appropriately;
Ensuring they have undertaken the relevant training and follow pharmacy standard operating procedures before undertaking tasks;
Reporting medication errors and near miss incidents involving CDs using the incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy;

Where rostered, undertaking a CD audit in a timely manner in accordance with departmental procedure. Pharmacists and registered pharmacy technicians must work with ward/dept. managers and authorised ward staff to resolve any CD issues.
Registered Agency Nurse/Midwife/ODP
Ensuring they do not become involved in the ordering of CDs;
Ensuring they should not undertake the CD stock check or administer CDs as the responsible person. They may however act as a witness for both the administration and stock checks;

Ensuring they only undertake ordering, administration and stock checks on the personal authorisation, in writing, from the Accountable Individual. This is in exceptional circumstances only (e.g. long period of time working for Trust).
Registered Bank Nurse/Midwife/ODP
Undertaking all activities as per a permanently based registrant;

Understanding that a record of any locations where they regularly work bank shifts should be submitted to pharmacy, authorised by the relevant accountable individual. They must be aware failure to do so may result in pharmacy refusal to supply any orders submitted.
Student Nurse, working under direct supervision
A student nurse is expected to gain experience in medicines management within the vocational elements of their course.
A student nurse must always ensure they are wearing their ID badge on display, and must understand that they are not Trust staff.
In Year 1 of training this is an observing only role, and in year 2 onwards this is a practical undertaking role with direct supervision.
4.22.1  They may undertake the following;

Writing of a paper CD order under direct supervision from an authorised registrant who must countersign their order as the authorised person (where an electronic CD ordering system in use (e.g. CEDAR), the student cannot order CDs but can observe);

Transcribe a CD onto a new page in a CD register under direct supervision from an authorised registrant who must countersign their entry as the authorised person. A second registered nurse must then need to countersign as the “witness”;

Prepare a CD to administer (year 2 onwards only), including entering in the register, under direct supervision from an authorised registrant who must countersign the administration as the authorised person. A second registered nurse will then need to check the preparation and countersign the register. (i.e. the preparation and signing out of the CD register still has two registered nurses involved);

Administer a CD (year 2 onwards only), under direct supervision from an authorised registrant who must countersign the administration as the authorised person. A second registered nurse will need to check and witness the administration (i.e. the administration still has two registered nurses involved);

Undertake a CD stock check under direct supervision from an authorised registrant who must countersign the stock check as the authorised person. A second registered nurse will need to check and witness the full stock check process (i.e. the stock check still has two registered nurses involved);
Observe the receipt, return and disposal of CDs only.
Student Midwife working under direct supervision
A student midwife is expected to gain experience in medicines management within the vocational elements of their course.
A student midwife must always ensure they are wearing their ID badge on display, and must understand that they are not Trust staff.
They may observe CD processes undertaken by the registrant only.
Pharmacy Delivery Person/Porter
Ensuring only procedures laid down by pharmacy are followed;
Escalating all issues to the team leader within the site dispensary from where medicines are released;
Maintaining security of deliveries at all times.
All employees
All employees are responsible for observing the requirements of this document and for ensuring the safe and secure handling of CDs;
To escalate anything that is a cause for concern in line with Trust processes.
Controlled Drug Requirements
Controlled Drug controls at the Trust are grouped by their legal schedule and drugs with locally increased controls assigned to these schedules. This is outlined in the appendix 1 table.
All controlled drugs must be managed in accordance with appendix
Schedule 2 Controlled Drugs
5.3.1 All controlled drugs except those specified below will be treated as controlled drugs. A full list exists within the Misuse of Drug Regulations (2001).
5.3.2 Key requirements are:
Do require locking in a CD cupboard;
Do require register entries;
A CD order is legally required;
Prescription requirements for TTAs and outpatient prescriptions (see under prescribing CDs);
Records kept of collector for items dispensed on prescription.
Buprenorphine and Temazepam
5.4.1  All formulations are treated as full Schedule 2 controlled drugs, increased from schedule 3. This is to ensure simplified processes in clinical areas and to enable better monitoring oversight.
Midazolam 10mg/2ml (high strength) injection only
5.5.1 The 10mg/2ml injection formulation only is treated as a full Schedule 2 controlled drug, increased from schedule 3.
5.5.2 Mis-selection of high strength midazolam is part of an NHS Never Event, where incorrect administration of midazolam is implicated in severe patient harm incidents.
Midazolam 1mg/1ml (and equivalent low strength) injection and buccal Midazolam only
5.6.1  There are no increased controls for these preparations. Please see section 5.7.
All other schedule 3 controlled drugs
5.7.1 The drugs stocked this applies to include pregabalin, gabapentin, tramadol, phenobarbitone and Meprobamate.
5.7.2 These are managed as per their legal requirement which is:
Do not require locking in a CD cupboard;
Do not require register entries;
A CD order is legally required;
Prescription requirements for TTAs and outpatient prescriptions (see under prescribing CDs);
Records kept of collector for items dispensed on prescription.
Potassium Chloride 15%w/v and AddiPHOS® ampoules
5.8.1 These preparations are treated as a full Schedule 2 controlled drug, even though they legally are not controlled drugs. This is nationally accepted practice.
5.8.2 Mis-selection of potassium chloride is part of an NHS Never Event, implicated in fatal consequences.
5.8.3 All requirements apply to both inpatient supplies from the hospital pharmacy and Patient's own CDs.
Controlled Drugs Cupboard Requirements
All Controlled Drugs requiring safe custody must be stored in a locked cupboard designated for the purpose and access must be restricted to staff who can legally be in possession.

Access to the CD cupboard must only be available to persons who can lawfully be in possession of CDs i.e. the registered Nurse/Midwife in Charge. Authorised Pharmacy Staff are permitted access for the purposes of audit, stock balance checks or return of CDs for destruction.
Controlled Drugs Cupboards must always be kept locked when not in use, and be in an area or room that can be secured when unattended.
No other medicines or items should normally be stored in the CD cupboard, other than Controlled Drug stationary - see section 11.6.
Controlled Drugs Cupboards must conform to British Standard reference BS2881 or be otherwise approved by the pharmacy department before procurement.

Cupboard construction must be made of steel with suitable hinges and securely attached to a wall or floor with an anchored bolt (rag bolt) or secure fixing as advised by the CD cupboard manufacturer. The fixings must not be accessible from outside the cabinet. If there is not a solid wall to fix the CD cupboard to, a steel plate must be mounted onto the wall and the CD cupboard attached to it.
The lock must not be common to any other lock in the hospital (i.e. no master key) with a multi-point locking mechanism (BS 3621:1998).
The cupboard key can only be removed when in the locked position (this is so the cupboard cannot be closed to give the appearance that it is locked).
The key must meet the British standard and have at least 5 levers or a six-pin Euro profile.

A cupboard within a cupboard is not a legal requirement for storage of CDs. Where existing clinical areas have CDs stored in a cupboard inside a medicines cupboard the internal CD cupboard must meet the requirements for Controlled Drug cabinets and locks.

A warning light/audible sound to indicate when the CD cupboard is open is not a legal requirement. In areas not continuously manned by nursing staff (i.e. part closure areas), a warning light is recommended. Always seek advice from the site pharmacy Medication Safety team before procurement.
Controlled Drug segregation and storage requirements
Controlled Drug cupboards must be of sufficient size for the number of items stocked and to ensure segregation in line with this section.

CDs must be stored at temperatures below 25°C or as otherwise specified on the product label (i.e. some locations may stock infusions that require refrigerated storage 2-8°C). Both rooms and fridges must be monitored in line with the Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines (MSEPO-20205).
If CDs require fridge storage the fridge must be securely attached to a wall or floor, and always be locked.
Stored CDs must be separated for safety, namely:
High strength opiates separate from lower strength;
Patients' own & TTA CDs separate from inpatient CDs;
Acceptable methods of segregating CDs in the CD cupboard are:
Using two adjacent CD cupboards in the same location;
Separate shelves within a CD cupboard;
In low use areas baskets may be placed on a shelf within the CD cupboard.
These are to be labelled (e.g. shelf-edge sticker) as to what is stored in each.

Holding Controlled Drug Cupboard Keys

The Nurse in Charge, Midwife or Senior ODP, if appropriate, is responsible for the CD keys. The person in charge is responsible for controlling access to the CD keys and access to CD cupboard on that ward or department for that shift.

Only ONE set of CD cupboard keys may ever exist in a clinical area. The ward manager is responsible for ensuring this is the case. Spare sets must never be held anywhere in the Trust, except the site pharmacy department.

The CD key must be kept separate from all other medicine cabinet keys. This ensures access is restricted to authorised staff. The only exceptions are the Universal Key(s) for McKinley T34 pumps, the keys for PCA pump/cassettes and CD transportation padlock keys (where used).
The CD key must be held in person by the Nurse or Midwife in Charge or Senior ODP and never in a drawer, never hanging up.

For some clinical areas that close (i.e. at weekends) when the area is not in use, keys must be locked in a secure cabinet. Only authorised persons to handle CD keys must have access to the secure cabinet.
Specific theatre key holding must be covered in departmental procedures. See section 43.
At the shift changeover, the nurse in charge must hand the keys to the Nurse in Charge of the next shift, who then assumes responsibility for the custody of CD's on the ward.
Under no circumstances must the CD keys leave the ward/ department.
During a shift it may be necessary to hand over the keys to another registered healthcare professional. All healthcare professionals in charge of CD keys must
make every effort to ensure they are only passed to other registered healthcare professionals who have a valid reason for needing the keys.
CD keys cannot be held by nursing assistants/support workers or student nurses/midwives.

The keys must be returned to the Nurse or Midwife in Charge immediately after use. The assigned key holder will challenge members of staff who request the keys to ensure that they have a legitimate and acceptable reason to access the CD cupboards and valid photo identification.
The registered healthcare professional in possession of keys must ensure that the CD cupboard is kept locked at all times.
If the CD cupboard keys cannot be located after every effort has been made to find them, the person responsible for the keys must follow section 9.
Missing Controlled Drug Keys
If the CD keys cannot be found the responsible registered nurse, midwife or clinical professional in charge of the care area must be informed immediately.

Urgent efforts must be made to retrieve the keys as speedily as possible. This is to include contacting nursing staff who have just gone off duty, or others who may have been given access to the keys e.g. authorised pharmacy staff, as appropriate. It is expected that if keys have been taken home by staff that they are returned immediately, without exception.
An incident form must be submitted regardless of whether the keys are found and returned or not.

The relevant Matron and ward/department registered pharmacy technician/ registered pharmacist must be informed as soon as practical. Out of hours, pharmacy must be informed immediately the next working day. They will liaise with the lead pharmacist for the directorate and pharmacy operations manager. The CD Accountable Officer will be informed as appropriate.

Depending on the circumstances it may be appropriate to contact the police. This decision will be made by the CD Accountable Officer in consultation with the Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS). If wrong doing is suspected the police should be involved.
Obtaining CDs for urgent administration

9.6.1  If a dose needs to be administered urgently the registered healthcare professional in charge must arrange to obtain this from the adjacent ward, in this situation ONLY. Any concerns over timely access to CDs during this time must be discussed with the ward/on call pharmacist without delay.
Spare Keys

9.7.1  Some areas, on some sites, may hold a spare CD key in the pharmacy department. The responsible nurse-in-charge (or equivalent) can contact pharmacy to supply the spare key, if one is available. A telephone request must be made prior to presentation at pharmacy, to determine if one exists.
Gaining access to CD cupboard

9.8.1 Where there is no spare key and the key cannot be located after sufficient investigation, then access to the CD cupboard needs to be arranged via the estates department. This must be authorised by the site Pharmacy Operations Manager, or designated deputy (acting for the CD Accountable Officer). Out of hours the on-call pharmacist will authorise this.

9.8.2 If the CD cupboard cannot be opened and then securely closed urgent efforts should be made to relocate stock to another suitable CD cupboard. This may have to be on a neighbouring ward, where transferred stock must be clearly segregated (within a container/ re-sealable bag).
Replacing a CD cupboard lock

9.9.1 Where the lock cannot be fixed, a replacement must be ordered immediately by the nurse-in-charge as an ‘Urgent request', via the estates department. The nurse/midwife-in-charge is responsible for ensuring the request is chased.
9.9.2 The replacement lock must meet the CD lock requirements.
9.9.3 Note: The pharmacy department does not order or supply any new locks for any department.
9.9.4 On arrival of the lock/ replacement cupboard, the keys must remain in the possession of the nurse/midwife-in-charge.
9.9.5 Facilities should be requested to ‘Urgently' fit the lock / cupboard. Under no circumstances must the keys be surrendered to facilities staff.
9.9.6 On completion, any spare sets of new keys must be sent to pharmacy in person.
Ward/Dept. closures and relocations

The site Pharmacy Operations manager / on-call pharmacist must be informed of all non-routine temporary or permanent closures. This ensures all pharmacy processes can be aligned as soon as possible and any issues identified promptly.
Ward/Department Relocation

10.2.1 If a ward is moving directly from one location to another, two registered healthcare professionals are responsible for the transfer of CDs between locations. A registered pharmacist, registered pharmacy technician or competency authorised pre-registration pharmacist may be one or more of these. Both members of staff must be present throughout the whole process.

10.2.2 The register is checked against the physical stock corresponding to the page in the CD register. General Principles for using the CD Register
This section applies to clinical areas (see also appendix 4). A specific pharmacy CD register is utilised in site pharmacy dispensaries, in accordance with pharmacy departmental procedures.
Entries must be clear and legible and written in ink, or otherwise indelible.
All entries must be made in chronological order.
An index of all preparations in stock should be kept at the front of the book, must match the relevant page in register, and be maintained.
Page numbers of the CD registers do not correspond with any CD order numbers (serial number of requisitions).
Separate pages should be kept for each drug and strength. The top of each page in the register must be completed namely:
Drug name;
Form;
Strength/concentration;
Vial/amps size (if applicable);
Proprietary name (if applicable).

Where similar products exist it is important to distinguish between them e.g. modified release and normal release (plain) formulations. Note this includes infusion preparations (i.e. ‘Morphine PCA' is NOT sufficient, as no strength is specified, and different ones exist within the organisation).
Entries must be made at the time of the transaction (receipt, supply, administration, destruction or return to pharmacy).

All entries must be signed by the registered nurse, midwife, ODP or registered doctor, and be witnessed, preferably by a second registered nurse, midwife or ODP. If a second registered nurse, midwife or ODP is not available, then the transaction can be witnessed by a registered pharmacist or registered pharmacy technician, in exceptional circumstances.
Entering received CDs into the CD Register

All oral tablets/capsules and injection CDs received are entered on the same page as existing stock, of the exact same medicine (i.e. rolling stock balance). The order is entered on the next available blank line. There is a space to record the order number (serial number of the requisition).

All oral liquid CDs received must be entered on a separate new page in the CD register. The entire bottle must be reconciled upon emptying and balance returned to zero. Do not use rolling balances as this is implicated in cumulative volume discrepancies. The index is updated accordingly.
Non-stocked CDs are entered on a separate new page in the CD register. The index is updated accordingly. Each receipt of drugs entry must record the following details:
Date Received (ditto marks or arrows to indicate the same day or time is NOT acceptable);
Amount received in words;
Order number (Serial number of Requisition);
The words ‘received from pharmacy' in the patient's name column;
Signature of the responsible registered person receiving the CD;
Signature of an authorised witness (e.g. registered nurse, midwife, doctor, dentist or pharmacist);
Updated stock balance (checking that the new stock balance tallies with the quantity that is physically present).
Transferring balances in the CD register
Transferring stock balances to a new page in the CD register (see appendix 4).
Once a page in the CD register is completed (i.e. is full), any remaining balance of the CD must be transferred to the next available blank page.
Before beginning the page transfer, the stock balance of the CD to be transferred must be physically checked as being correct by two registered healthcare professionals.
The next available blank page is located. At the bottom of the full page the next page number is written in the ‘carried over to page number….' section.

On the new page the previous page number is written in the ‘carried forward from page number….' section. The balance carried over is then written in the ‘balance on transfer' box in the ‘stock balance' column. A transaction line is not required.
The transferring staff must then complete the top of the next blank page in the register as per section 22. The index page is updated accordingly.

The number of the new page must be updated onto the label of the medicine. The transferring staff must cross out the original number but it must still be possible to see what that original number was. The new page number must also be fully legible on the medicine container.
Transferring balances to a new CD register
Once all the pages are full in the CD register a new CD Register must be started.

The new CD register can be used alongside the old register for up to one month so as to reduce the number of transfers over into the new register. During this time the ward/dept. should ensure the items in the old register are used before any from the new register.

Two registered healthcare professionals should transfer over the outstanding items from the old register into the new one. The stock balance of the CD to be transferred must be physically checked as being correct.
The available blank page in the new register is located.

Both the page number of the new page and number of the new register (found on top left on front of register) are entered at the bottom of the full page in the ‘carried over to page number….' section. This ensures a clear audit trail between one register and another.
On the new page, in the new register, the previous page number and previous register number is written in the ‘carried forward from page number….' section.
The balance carried over is then written in the ‘balance on transfer' box in the ‘stock balance' column. A transaction line is not required.
The transferring staff must then complete the top of the new page in the register as per section 22. The index page is updated accordingly.

The number of the new page must be updated onto the label of the medicine. The transferring staff must cross out the original number but it must still be possible to see what that original number was. The new page number must also be fully legible on the medicine container.

Once a register has been completed in full, with no transactions it should be closed down. The registered healthcare professionals closing the register should enter the closure date on the front of the CD register and a destroy date (two years after closure date). The CD Register must be safely and securely stored on the ward for at least two years.
CDs for patients transferred between hospitals/care settings
Controlled drugs for patients to be transferred between hospitals:
24.1.1 When a controlled drug is required for administration to a patient during a transfer, it shall be provided by the clinical area from which the patient is to be transferred.

24.1.2 The drug shall be prescribed on a Trust drug chart and an appropriate quantity of the drug shall be drawn up into the syringe. The syringe will be labelled with the name and strength of the drug
24.1.3 A registered nurse will enter details in the clinical area controlled drugs register and will endorse the entry “patient transfer to (name of clinical area/hospital)”
24.1.4 The patient should be accompanied on the journey by a doctor or registered Nurse who will sign the controlled drugs register in the witness column

24.1.5 The doctor or registered nurse is responsible for recording the amount of drug administered during the journey and for ensuring safe destruction of any drug remaining on arrival at the destination clinical area of hospital

24.1.6 Destruction of the drug remaining on arrival should be entered into the back of the CD register of the destination ward/department. The entry should be in same style as for a syringe pump at the back of the register (see appendix 8). The entry must state where the syringe has come from (e.g. originating hospital name and ward).
Controlled drugs for patients transferred between clinical areas/care settings
24.2.1 Patients are frequently transferred between clinical areas or care settings with continuous infusions in progress.

24.2.2 Trust staff admitting patients from another clinical area or care setting must have access to appropriate documentation to support the medication and integrity of the preparation; to maintain patient safety.

24.2.3 It is the responsibility of the nurse in charge to ensure that any infusion equipment used to administer the controlled drug is correctly set prior to patient transfer; and that syringes or bags containing controlled drugs are correctly labelled.
24.2.4 It is the responsibility of the nurse in charge of the receiving clinical area to:
Check the infusion is adequately labelled and matches the prescription, including the strength and rate of infusion;
Check the integrity of the infusion by visual inspection and confirm pump is working;
Ensure the start time for the infusion is clear and remaining volume is appropriate.
24.2.5 If these details are confirmed, the infusion can continue.
24.2.6 If any of the information is unavailable or unclear, (and is within the Trust) contact the referring clinical team.
24.2.7 If all the details cannot be confirmed the infusion (and it's from another care setting) the infusion must be discarded and a new infusion prepared locally following Trust procedures.

24.2.8 If the patient is admitted from another Trust site or a non-Trust care setting - the medicines required during admission must be prescribed by a Trust authorised prescriber on Trust prescription stationery according to the medication history and patient clinical need.
24.2.9 A record must be made on the Trust prescription indicating the time initiated, along with the name of the organisation, signed and dated by Trust nurse/midwife confirming the details.
Correcting errors in the CD Register
Entries must be clear and unambiguous.

They must never be cancelled (e.g. crossed through), obliterated (e.g. scribbled over) or altered (e.g. overwritten). Liquid paper correction fluid (e.g. Tippex™), or sticky labels must never be used.
Pages or part-pages must never be torn out of any CD register.
If a mistake is made the original entry must remain clearly legible. A correction should be made elsewhere as below.
The error should be bracketed and be asterisked *.
An accompanying asterisked footnote should be made at the bottom of the page stating:
The words ‘Entered in error';
What the correction is;
Signature of the administering registrant;
Signature of the authorised witness;
Date and time.
If necessary, a new, separate correct entry should be made.
The expected standard of entries is given in appendix 5.
Undertaking CD Stock Checks

A routine stock check is the checking of all stock balances, for all CD registers in use (including patient's own CD register), against the physical quantity of all CD stocks present in the CD cupboard/s; and reconciling discrepancies.
For all general wards & departments the routine stock check of all CDs must be undertaken for at each shift change (see appendix 6).
For all theatres, CDs must be checked at the end of every session so as to ensure all doses administered have been recorded in the register.
The registered nurse/midwife in charge is responsible for ensuring that the routine CD stock check is undertaken by authorised staff, and witnessed.
Stock checks are also undertaken as part of the routine CD Audit undertaken by pharmacy staff.
The person carrying out the routine stock check must be a registered nurse or midwife (first signatory for the stock check).

The person witnessing the stock check can be a second registered nurse, midwife or other registered healthcare professional (e.g. pharmacist, ODP, radiographer). After completion of a set of pharmacy-agreed competencies a senior pharmacy assistant can be authorised to witness controlled drug checks across the Trust in line with this policy. The CD checks must only be carried out with a registered member of the nursing or theatre team. The CD checks must never be carried out by 2 members of the pharmacy team.

The CD register must be used as the main source of checking what items are present in stock. If the items are only taken out of the cupboard and checked against the relevant page then it is possible for missing containers not to be accounted for.
The CD register should be checked front to back, systematically turning through the pages.
All pages of the CD register should be checked to ensure there are no missing pages.
All registers must be checked; even if no drugs are expected to be in stock (i.e. patients own and TTA CD register).
Checks should take account of the following points:
Checking the stock balance of each item in the CD register against physical stock;
That the CD register page number/s matches that stated on the stock label. If not this is immediately updated;
Expiry date check of every container of CDs, taking note of expiry dates once opened (liquids have 6 months from dispensing if packed down, unless otherwise stated on the label);
Checking the label exactly matches the CDs found inside (e.g. same strength / formulation on all strips of tablets);
Counting both sides of blister strips of tablets/capsules to ensure that the drug is definitely present and not popped out;
Taking patches out of their boxes and feeling each individual patch. The check must verify that individual patch wrappers are sealed and a patch can be felt inside;
The contents of opened boxes should be examined and individual ampoules, tablets etc. confirmed to be correct;

It is not necessary to open original packs with intact tamper-evident seals for stock checking purposes. Opened packs should never be re-sealed for the purpose of avoiding having to count the stock subsequently.
CD liquid volumes

26.13.1 These do not have to be checked in a measuring cylinder every day. Regular measurements can add to the wastage of liquids as small amounts are left in any cylinders; particularly for the more viscous liquids.
26.13.2 Some liquid containers may have approximate measures on the side of the container so the volume which is remaining according to the register should be checked against the label.
26.13.3 If there is any suspicion there is less liquid in the bottle than the register level then a full volume check must be made.
26.13.4 The balance must be confirmed to be correct on completion of each bottle.
On returning the CDs to the CD cupboard, care must be taken to ensure they are correctly segregated (see section 7).
Once the check has been undertaken one entry must be made on the stock check page at the back of the register. This must document:
Date and time;
Signature of registrant checking;
Signature of person witnessing;
Declaring if all items are correct by stating ‘Yes' or ‘No';
If ‘No', stating details of any discrepancies (i.e. page number and what is not correct).
If a discrepancy is found it must be investigated without delay, and this must follow section 28.
Managing CD Discrepancies

If a discrepancy is found involving a CD action must be taken as soon as possible, as any delays can make it impossible to identify what has happened. The identifying person must inform the registered nurse or midwife in charge immediately.
There are two possible scenarios: either the CD register amount is greater than the physical amount present or the CD register amount is less than the physical amount present.

The registered nurse or midwife in charge must investigate any discrepancy immediately. If they are unavailable, their deputy or a matron must undertake this role. Every possible step must be explored and this can take time but it is necessary to complete the entire investigation. An investigation must consider the legal aspects as well as impact on any patients involved.
For discrepancies within pharmacy only, the site dispensary manager, or equivalent, must undertake this role.
Discrepancies are either ‘simple record-keeping' errors or are otherwise ‘complex'. These require different responses.
Simple record-keeping errors
27.6.1 Simple record-keeping errors are typically where there is a straightforward calculation error, or a minor documentation issue only.

27.6.2 The cause of the discrepancy must have been immediately identified (i.e. within a few minutes) and the cause of the discrepancy is without any doubt (i.e.100% sure). A pharmacist should be consulted for advice, if needed.
27.6.3 Simple record-keeping entries may be corrected in the register as per section

The correcting registrant must be witnessed. It is good practice for the two persons involved not to be the same as the registrants involved in the error. Where there is not another available registrant to do this then a pharmacist must witness the correction.
27.6.4 Ensure the resolution of the discrepancy is updated on the stock check page in the register, if found at a routine stock check.
Complex discrepancies
27.7.1 Complex means that the cause of the discrepancy cannot be found immediately and/or there is doubt as to the cause of the discrepancy (including not being satisfied with explanations given).

27.7.2 If the discrepancy remains unresolved, the registered healthcare professional in charge must also immediately informed verbally (emails should be avoided in case they are not picked up promptly):
the Matron (duty Sister in charge if out of hours);
the ward/dept. named Pharmacist (if out of hours this must be done the next day). They in turn will liaise with the appropriate pharmacy staff, and CDAO if appropriate.
For complex discrepancies an incident report form must be submitted as soon as possible, regardless of whether the discrepancy was subsequently resolved or not.
Complex discrepancy investigations must be recorded on the CD discrepancy investigation form available on the intranet or from pharmacy.
The contents of the investigation must include:
Detailed specifics about the discrepancy (e.g. register page numbers, drug involved and timings of when identified and when stock checks last undertake);
Staff on duty for the time period concerned, identifying those who had CD keys in their possession prior to the identified discrepancy;
Written statements from all appropriate staff members;

Key findings that might have a bearing on the discrepancy (examples may include CD policy non-compliances: CD register entries signed by only one person; illegible, incomplete, ambiguously corrected or crossed out entries);
Conclusions made.
Some discrepancies will warrant greater concern than others such as the amount of discrepancy involved.
Oral Liquid discrepancies
27.12.1 With respect to oral liquids, the investigation must consider if the amount of loss is acceptable. The following must be considered and documented:
Is the discrepancy less than 5% of the total volume dispensed?
What is the number of administrations from the bottle? The more administrations the greater the opportunity for discrepancies to occur;

What is the volume of each of doses have been administered from the bottle? The volume discrepancy per dose may or may not be significant. Patient safety as well and CD documentation is an important consideration here if there is evidence of possible over or under dosing. For example a 0.5ml discrepancy per dose for a 5ml dose may be considered differently from 0.5ml discrepancy per dose for a 2.5ml dose;
What is the method of dose measurement by all staff in the clinical area?
27.12.2 Example considerations to judge acceptability may include:

Discrepancy is within 5% of the total volume for a 250mL bottle (i.e. up to 12.5ml out). There have been more than 12 administration episodes from the same bottle. This will make the discrepancy, per administration, of around 1mL or less. A patient was prescribed 2.5ml but possibly received, on average, 3.5ml each time.

Discrepancy is within 5% of total volume though there have been 3 administration episodes from the same bottle. This would make the discrepancy, per administration, of over 4ml. The patient was prescribed 2.5ml but possibly received, on average, 6.5ml each time.
Measuring cups being used inappropriately to measure liquids rather than accurate oral syringes.
27.12.3 The CD discrepancy investigation form must be completed electronically by the registered nurse/midwife in charge and emailed to the address on the form. See appendix

27.12.4 The CDAO must be informed immediately where there is any suspicion of misuse or diversion (i.e. theft / fraud). They will co-ordinate any further investigation in collaboration with the Trust Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS).

27.12.5 The CDAO and/or LSMS will authorise and liaise, as appropriate, with the Essex Controlled Drugs Liaison Officer (Essex Police). They will inform the relevant commissioning body Accountable Officer to ensure the Essex Controlled Drugs Intelligence Network is aware.

27.12.6 Every CD discrepancy investigation form is reviewed by a designated site registered pharmacy technician. They support the site pharmacy operations manager and CDAO in determining any further actions, if appropriate.
27.12.7 For complex discrepancies the corrective entry in the CD register may only be witnessed by registered pharmacy staff acting on authority from the site pharmacy operations manager and CDAO.
27.12.8 The incident form must be updated with the outcome of the investigation.
27.12.9 If the discrepancy was found at a routine stock check, this page should be updated to reflect the outcome of the discrepancy investigation.
27.12.10 Pharmacy maintains records of all staff involved and themes/trends with discrepancies for all clinical locations and pharmacy dispensaries, for all sites.

27.12.11 Any identified cause for concern such as repeat involvement of the same staff, same clinical locations or same CD preparations involved will initiate formal action plans issued by the CDAO to the relevant clinical area managers.
27.12.12 Outcomes and learning from investigations are submitted to the regional NHS CD local intelligence network (CDLIN) quarterly by the CDAO, and exception reported at MSE Hospitals MOC.
Authority to administer and second checking of CDs

A registered nurse, registered midwife, registered Operating Department Practitioner (ODP), medical practitioner or another authorised registered healthcare professional may administer a CD in accordance with a legal prescription for the item.
Registered midwives have specific provisions in law to possess and administer some CDs in the course of their professional practice. See section 44 for details.

Administration of CDs via the intravenous or epidural route must only be undertaken by registered health care professionals, who have undergone specific additional training and have demonstrated their competency.

The administering registrant must enlist a second authorised registrant to witness the whole procedure. The witness must be another registered nurse/midwife, ODP, a medical practitioner or a registered pharmacist.

Student nurses may act as a witness but this witnessing must be under direct supervision by a second registered nurse who will countersign their witness entry in the register (i.e. the administration still has two registered nurses involved). Refer also to section 4.22.1. Student midwives may not act as the witness signature for the administration of CDs.

In general ward areas both registrants must remain present throughout the entire procedure of removal from CD cupboard, checking, preparation and administration of the CD and destruction of drug not required. It is not acceptable for two registrants to select and prepare a dose of a CD for administration by a third person.

In theatre and intensive care areas, one registrant may be unable to leave the bedside. Therefore the removal from CD cupboard, checking, and preparation may involve two registrants; of which one then passes to a third administering practitioner (see also theatre section 43).

Both registered persons are accountable for their actions but the accountability and responsibility for the accuracy of the administration is with the registrant who actually administers the medication (the ‘responsible person').
There are exceptions to the need for a second checker (witness) where a single registered nurse/midwife can administer the following controlled drugs:
Gabapentin (all forms);
Pregabalin (all forms);
Tramadol (all forms);
Phenobarbitone / Phenobarbital (Oral formulations only).
Administering CDs process
Administration of CDs is as for any other medicine, and therefore all requirements for medicines administration as per the site administration of medicines policy (or equivalent) apply.
Prescription / authority to administer check
29.2.1  The administering registrant must read the prescription / authority to administer carefully and check the following:
Patient's name & date of birth;
Age and weight, if appropriate;
Allergies or hypersensitivities recorded;
Name of medicine to be administered, dose, frequency and form;
Date and time the dose is due;
Route;
Time of previous dose, if any (note previous prescriptions of different doses);
Signature of prescriber and date of prescription;
Verify that the dose has not already been given.
For opiate medicines the following additional checks are required:

If the patient has not previously been administered an opioid then the dose should be considered as to whether it is a sensible initiation dose. High opioid doses should only be used in patients that have had their dose increased over time.
Be aware of any other opiates co-prescribed and be assured that they are required alongside each other.
If the dose of the opioid has been increased, a safe dose sense check should be calculated. This normally will be an increase of only 50% or less. Any dose increase of more than 50% may not be right.
Time of previous dose is important with opiates because of the risk of overdose through dosing too close together (e.g. ‘when required' use and 12hourly long-acting tablets).

29.3.1 The administering registrant must challenge all prescriptions which do not look right. If the registered healthcare professional has any queries which cannot be answered by checking in the BNF/BNF for Children and local Trust guidelines, then they must contact either the prescribing doctor or the pharmacist before administering the dose.
29.3.2 The authorised witness should also be satisfied by the prescription and all relevant checks as a matter of good professional practice.

29.3.3 The administering registrant must carry out any calculations required to ascertain the amount or volume to be administered. The witness must make any calculations independently, without knowledge of the administrator's calculation results. The results of these separate calculations must agree before carrying out the next step.
CD Preparation Check

29.4.1 The administering registrant and the witness must open the CD cupboard and select the appropriate medicine. CDs may only be administered to inpatients from stock, or a patient's own CD if for that named patient (see section 35).
29.4.2 This is checked against the prescription / authority to administer:
Name of medicine;
Strength;
Preparation (confirming that it is suitable to be administered by the route prescribed);

For tablets check whether the medicine is slow release which is usually given every  hours or immediate release which are prescribed when required or four hourly. Take particular care with sound alike-look-alike medicines as these can be confusing;
Expiry date.
29.4.3 The controlled drug stock must be checked to ensure that the stock balance correctly tallies with that in the CD register. Any identified discrepancies must be managed as per section 28.
29.4.4 The administering registrant must prepare the correct dose for administration and lock the remaining CDs away in the CD cupboard.
29.4.5 All oral liquid CDs must be measured only using a Trust approved oral syringe. Measuring cups are not accurate and are not to be used.
29.4.6 A CD register entry is required for all CDs removed from the CD cupboard for administration (see appendix 8).
29.4.7 Each entry must include:
Date & Time (using the 24 hour clock). Ditto marks or arrows to indicate the same day or time are NOT acceptable;
Patient name and NHS or Hospital number. This ensures full traceability of all transactions;
Amount (entered under ‘S', ‘A' or ‘D') – see below;
Both a Responsible person signature and a Witness signature;
A new stock balance calculated, checked and documented.
29.4.8 Each transaction line is set out as S.A.D. This means:
S = Supplied: what is being supplied from the CD cupboard to make the dose;
A = Administered: what is the actual dose that was administered to the patient;
D = Destroyed: what amount was destroyed because it was the remainder left in the ampoule/vial or was not administered (tablet spat out / infusion stopped early etc.).

29.4.9 Entries in the CD register should only be made after the task has been completed. For example doses should not be signed as administered until they have actually been administered and witnessed.
Documenting part ampoules/vials used to prepare a dose
If part of an ampoule / vial is used to prepare a dose, the amount of wasted medicine must be recorded, and destroyed.
e.g. if the patient is prescribed 2.5mg morphine and only a 10mg ampoule is available, the record should show “10mg Supplied (S), 2.5mg Administered (A) and 7.5mg Destroyed (D)”.
Any surplus drug must be destroyed to be irretrievable. This must be in accordance with section 33, and be witnessed.
29.5.1 The administering registrant and the witness must take the medicine and the drug chart to the area in which the administration is to take place.

29.5.2 The administering registrant must check the identity of the patient, by verbally checking with the patient, by checking the identity band and ensuring both correspond with the information on the prescription /authority to administer.
29.5.3 The administering registrant must explain the procedure and the purpose of the medication to the patient and where appropriate obtain their verbal consent to the intended administration.

29.5.4 The administering registrant must administer the CD preparation, witnessed by the second authorised person. For oral administrations, the patient must be witnessed taking the preparation. Doses must never be left with the patient on the presumption that they will take the preparation.
29.5.5 The registrants must make an immediate record of administration at the patient's bedside on the drug chart.
29.5.6 If for any particular reason the dose cannot be given e.g. the patient refuses then this must also be noted in the CD register.

29.5.7 Individual doses of CDs prepared but not administered (e.g. patient refuses or spits out the medication) must be recorded immediately in the CD register and on the drug chart. Please see appendix 8. A new entry will need to be made in the CD register to account for the prepared dose that was not given. This must then be destroyed, to be irretrievable, and witnessed as per section 33. The relevant non-administered code must be entered on the drug chart and details recorded in the patient healthcare record.

29.5.8 Drowsiness and level of consciousness must be monitored in patients receiving CDs. Administering registrants must be competent to recognise and treat any deterioration in a patient's condition and / or any known adverse effects that require immediate life support intervention, such as anaphylaxis, respiratory depression and cardiac arrest.

29.5.9 For continuous administration (e.g. via syringe pumps) a record must be made of the registrants involved in setting up the medication and of those subsequently involved in monitoring the administration and the patient's
condition. Documentation and advice on doing this is set out in the site Syringe Pump policies and procedures or equivalent.
29.5.10 Administration via the intravenous route is restricted to the following locations and situations where sufficient patient monitoring can take place to ensure patient safety. These are:
Cardiac Care Units and other monitored cardiac beds
Critical Care/Intensive Care Units
High Dependency Units
Accident and Emergency Departments
Neonatal Units
All Theatres
All Post-op locations

29.5.11 For any other area (e.g. acute medical admissions unit), administration and monitoring may only be carried out by a competent registered nurse where they will be maintaining 1:1 nursing with the patient throughout for acute cardiac chest pain.
Patient-Controlled Analgesia Devices (PCAs)
29.6.1 If the patient is then transferred to another ward or department the PCA prescription on the drug chart details of the name, form, strength and volume of PCA set up for the patient.
29.6.2 No further record is required of the exact volume transferred with the patient to the receiving ward or department.

29.6.3 Replacement PCAs can be set-up and administered as per normal practice with all other CDs. The new PCA device set-up must be recorded on the drug chart and CD register. The relevant ward registered nurse-in-charge is responsible for ensuring they have sufficient stock present for receiving patients on a PCA.
Recording part-wasted PCAs, epidurals and syringe pumps
The remaining amounts of any part-administered infusions (i.e. PCAs, epidurals syringe pumps) must be destroyed, and the CD made irretrievable, see section 33.
A record must be made in the CD register and must be witnessed the same as for all administration processes.
The expected standard of entries is given in appendix 8.
For part-administered amounts, enter at the back of the inpatient register, from page 150 working backwards:
Enter Date, patient name and hospital number;

Across the ‘S' and ‘A' rows an entry should state the words ‘syringe pump' (or PCA or epidural etc.) followed by the full contents of that preparation. Include the CD register page references. There may be more than one if it is a syringe pump made from two controlled drugs;
The destroyed amount (D) is entered as the volume of drug remaining, signed and witnessed;
A stock balance is not required on this page because the components of the syringe pump, the PCA, or the epidural have already been documented on the relevant pages of the CD register.
Breakages and Defective CDs
Accidental breakage of an ampoule or other fragile container has been known to occur from time to time.
Single instances of breakage can be discarded and safely disposed of on the ward in the presence of two registered nurses/ midwives as described in section
33. If a second Registered Nurse is not available on the ward at the time, another registrant should witness the presence of a breakage and subsequent destruction.
The broken item/s need to be accounted for so should be signed out of the CD register by the two registered Nurses, stating the reason.
In all cases of broken ampoules the Nurse/ Midwife in Charge of the Ward/ Department should be informed.

If a CD medicine is broken on receipt or found to be defective (i.e. ampoules already broken or cracked, the contents appear cloudy or appear to contain contamination), the item(s) should be clearly marked “do not use,” and retained in the CD cupboard, separate from other CDs. Pharmacy should be contacted to return the stock as soon as possible. These should not be destroyed on the ward/dept. as further investigation may be necessary.

For broken on receipt or defective CDs registered pharmacy staff will assess any identified problems. They will remove the offending items and make appropriate entries in the CD register. If necessary, they will also report the problem to the manufacturers and check any remaining pharmacy stocks.
Destruction of CDs in Clinical Areas
It is a requirement that CDs no longer needed are destroyed in such a way that the drug is denatured or rendered irretrievable so that it cannot be reconstituted or re-used.
The following CDs only may be destroyed in the clinical area:
Surplus amounts when the dose prepared is less than the contents of the vial/ampoule used;
Part-administered discontinued infusions (i.e. syringe pumps, epidurals, PCAs);
Broken or damaged individual doses /ampoules etc.;
Residual liquid in ‘empty' oral liquid bottles;
Dropped solid dosage forms (i.e. tablets/capsules);
Medicines prepared but not administered (including popped out tablets/capsules);
Used patches removed from patients.
For all other CDs, these must be returned to pharmacy for disposal, see section 34.
CDs must be destroyed promptly by the registered nurse/midwife and witnessed by a second registered person.
All CDs destroyed of must be accounted for by documenting in the CD register at the time of disposal.
Entries in the CD register for disposal must be as per appendix 8.

Controlled Drug destruction granules (e.g. safety gel) must be used to denature, and this is only available from pharmacy, on request. This product must never be used for any other purpose (see appendix 9)
32.7.1 Ingestion of these superabsorbent granules is implicated in severe harm and fatal incidents.
32.7.2 The powder granules are not toxic, but if placed in the mouth they will expand on contact with saliva, risking airway obstruction and asphyxiation.
32.7.3 The following practice points must be followed:
Always store the CD destruction granules in the original container supplied from pharmacy.

The CD destruction kit granules must always be kept secure and away from patients. This means store only within a locked medicine cupboard, ideally the CD cupboard, as all times and never removing from the designated drug room.
The method to destroy each type of drug is given in appendix

All destroyed CDs must be disposed of in a yellow sharps container. For areas that will routinely destroy amounts of CDs in the course of routine practice it is recommended as designated yellow sharps container is assigned. The containers must not be identified as containing CD waste.
CDs must never be discarded down a sink, sluice or drain.
Emptied CD medicine containers/infusion bags etc. must be disposed of via yellow clinical waste bags. Patient's identifiable details must be obliterated from empty containers before disposal.
Returning CDs to the pharmacy

The registered nurse, midwife or ODP in charge is responsible for ensuring CDs are returned to pharmacy as soon as possible. CDs should be returned within a 10 day period after the last date of administration of that CD (except ‘stock list' CDs) to avoid unnecessary accumulation of CDs.
CDs should be returned to the pharmacy if:
The CD has expired;
The CD is no longer required on the ward (e.g. the patient's drug treatment has changed, patient has left the ward);
The CD was dispensed for an individual patient, including patient's own CDs, that are required by the pharmacy relabeling for discharge;
Otherwise considered unfit for use.

The registered nurse/midwife-in-charge, or authorised delegate, should ask the ward/dept. pharmacy team to return medicines. A registered member of pharmacy staff will organise the return of the CD/s. If pharmacy staff have not returned the CDs within 72 hours then the pharmacy department should be contacted by telephone.
CDs must never be included amongst consignments of general unwanted medicines.
Where possible, the return of CDs will always be done at ward/department level, unless specifically advised otherwise by the registered pharmacy staff member.
CDs must never be removed from the CD cupboard and never signed out of the CDs register prior to the time of return.
When the registered nurse or midwife and the registered pharmacy staff member are both present, the CD/s may be returned.
CDs may only be given to a registered pharmacy staff member.

A stock balance check must be undertaken of the CD to be returned, and the appropriate checks made to ensure the correct CD has been selected. The indexed page number must match that on the labelled container. Special care must be taken with sound-alike, look-alike medicines. Where the CD is a liquid the volume must be measured and not estimated.
A transaction must be entered in the CD register stating:
Date and time of return, using the 24-hour clock;
Under patient name the words “Returned to pharmacy”;
Signature of registered pharmacy staff member receiving the drugs;
Signature of registered nurse/midwife handing over the drugs;
New Stock balance (this will usually be zero).
Stock list CDs which have not been used in the last month, or have expired should be considered for removal from the CD stock list.
Patient's own drugs are the property of the patient, so consent must be obtained before they are removed by pharmacy for destruction.

Patient's own CDs for deceased patients can be destroyed without the consent of the patient's estate (or relatives). This can be authorised by authorised registrant and authorised pharmacy staff witness.

A record of the each returned CD to pharmacy is made on the designated pharmacy CD returns paperwork (see pharmacy departmental SOPs). This is an auditable trail of the CDs from the ward/dept. CD register to the Pharmacy CD register. This must state:
Ward/Dept. Name;
Drug name, strength, form;
Amount;
Signature of the registered nurse/midwife handing over the CDs from the clinical area;
Signature of the registered pharmacy person receiving the CDs to return to pharmacy.
The return paperwork must be retained with the CDs that are returned to the pharmacy department.
The process of return and documentation on returns paperwork must be completed for each individual CD item returned.

Returned CDs must only be taken in a sealable container from the clinical area to pharmacy and never carried loosely. CDs must be taken immediately back to pharmacy and not via any other clinical location or areas.

The registered pharmacy staff member is responsible for the CD items from the moment signed out of the CD register until formal receipt into to the pharmacy department. CD must be entered into the appropriate pharmacy CD register, determined by whether the CDs are eligible for re-use or awaiting disposal. This is processed as per pharmacy departmental procedures and section 46 of this policy.
Patient's Own CDs and CDs dispensed for discharge (TTAs)
An audit trail must be maintained for all CDs including patient's own CDs and those dispensed on a TTA from pharmacy. Records must be made in the Patient's Own and TTA CD register (POD CD Register).
The POD CD register must be checked at every routine stock check, as per section 27; irrespective of whether the CDs are being administered or not.

All medicines (including over the counter medicines, GP prescribed medicines, medicines from previous hospital discharge or from other hospitals) brought into the hospital by patients remain their property throughout.
Patient's own CDs on the ward support the medicines reconciliation process, continuity of treatment, reduces unnecessary dispensing and improves discharge planning.

The patient should give permission for the CDs to be securely stored within the CD cupboard in the clinical area. They should not be in the patient's possession, in a bedside medication locker, or in the drugs trolley. Patient's own CDs, and those dispensed on a TTA ready for discharge must be stored separately from all other CDs in the CD cupboard (see section 7).

Should the patient not give permission, explanation of the legal requirements should be outlined to encourage compliance. However, staff should not place themselves at risk if a patient is exhibiting violent or aggressive behaviour. In this circumstance, arrangement must be made for the medicines to be returned home via an identified adult, as soon as possible. Responsibility for security is given to that adult. Ensure it is clearly documented in patient's notes that the patient has refused to give permission for the CDs to be stored in the ward/department CD cupboard.
Receipt of Patient's Own CDs
34.7.1 The suitability for use of patient's own CDs must be assessed in the same way as for other patient's own drugs.

34.7.2 CDs must be clearly identifiable as to what they are, such as labelling instructions and clearly readable blister packs (of tablets/capsules etc.). Loose strips must be grouped together (i.e. in a small resealable, labelled bag). If the medication is not labelled with patient details, label appropriately (i.e. with a patient addressograph sticker).
34.7.3 Where possible, patient's own CDs should be checked for suitability for use by a member of pharmacy staff prior to administration.
34.7.4 Patient's own CDs must be entered into the POD CD register, regardless of suitability. There is a designated box to tick on the page of the register indicating if suitable for administration.
34.7.5 If the medicines are not safe and/or appropriate for use, then the patient should be advised and encouraged to consent for collection by pharmacy for safe destruction.
Entering into CD register
34.8.1 The CD must be entered on the next available blank page in the POD CD register. Only one page, for each drug belonging to the patient must be used.
34.8.2 The following must be recorded at the top of each page of register:
Patient name and NHS/hospital number;
Drug name, form, strength of the CD preparation;
Quantity received (in dose units);
Date received;
Both authorised signatures from registered nurse/midwife and witness;
Declaration if suitable for administration ticked either YES or NO.
34.8.3 The page number of the register must be written on the label of the CD preparation and the CD locked in the patient's own area of the CD cupboard.
TTA CDs dispensed from Pharmacy

34.9.1 If the patient is being discharged immediately it is not necessary to make an entry into the POD CD register. The patient will be discharged with medication, provided exactly matches the discharge summary (TTA prescription).

34.9.2 Frequently, a patient's discharge prescription will be prepared in advance of their discharge home. In this case it must be recorded in the POD CD register and locked in the CD cupboard. If still suitable, the CD will be signed out at discharge (see below).
Administration of patients own CDs

34.10.1 If there is ward CD stock available, then this should normally be routinely used. On occasions it may be necessary to use a patient's own CD (e.g. because the medication is non-formulary or needed before pharmacy is open), provided suitable to use (see above).
34.10.2 Patient's own Drugs must never be used to treat another patient, under any circumstances.
34.10.3 Patient's own CDs may only be administered to the patient against a valid prescription order (i.e. inpatient drug chart) during their stay in hospital, as per any other medicine.
34.10.4 All doses administered to the patient must be recorded in the POD CD register.
34.10.5 The following must be recorded:
Date and Time, using the 24-hour clock;
Amount given;
Amount destroyed (if applicable, otherwise enter ‘zero');
Both authorised signatures from registered nurse/midwife and witness;
A new stock balance calculated, checked and documented.
Patient Consent for destruction

34.11.1 Where Patient's own CDs are no longer required the patient will be informed and verbal consent obtained for the pharmacy disposal of the medicines. Consent is documented in the patient consent box on that page of the POD CD register. Where agreement is not given the medicines should be returned to the patient with clear advice that they are no longer required, and explanation of the risks of keeping these medicines.

34.11.2 In some mental health & learning disabilities, where the patient may not have the capacity to make a decision, the CDs may be held on the ward until discharge. If the CDs are not safe and / or appropriate for use, then the patient and /or patient's representative should be advised and they should be encouraged to allow the destruction of the CDs.
Returning CDs to the patient

34.12.1 Where there are no changes to the medication or dose, patient's own CDs should be returned to them rather than new supplies dispensed. Patients with an on-going supply in place or sufficient for 2 weeks supply present should not be dispensed CDs on discharge, in most circumstances.
34.12.2 Before supplying the CD, the registered nurse/midwife must ensure that:
Patient is still prescribed this medicine on the current, final discharge prescription (TTA);
The dose, form AND frequency is the same.

34.12.3 If these criteria are not fulfilled, the medicine is not suitable for supply to patient. It should be returned to pharmacy (see section 34). The same process applies for CDs dispensed for discharge (TTA CDs).

34.12.4 If criteria are met, at the time of discharge, the CDs may be removed from the CD cupboard and signed out of the register. This must be done using the return section at bottom of the relevant page.
Transfer of CDs to another ward

34.13.1  If a patient is transferred between wards, the patient's own (or TTA-supplied) CD should be signed out of POD CD register (as per below), sent with the patient and handed immediately to the receiving registered nurse in charge to sign in their POD CD register.
Signing CDs out of the Register
34.14.1  When returning or transferring Patient's own or TTA CDs the following information must be recorded on the relevant page of the register:
Date;
Amount returned in the ‘Returned to Patient', Returning to pharmacy' or ‘Transferred to' column, as appropriate. Only one section must be completed;
If returning to pharmacy a declaration of patient consent ‘YES' or ‘NO';
If transferring to another ward, the name of the new ward;
Both the signature of registered nurse/midwife returning the CD and witness;
A new stock balance documented (which should be zero).
Suspected illegal substances
The Trust has a legal obligation to prevent illicit substance use and distribution on its premises.
The integrity of the care environment and safety of all those within is of paramount importance.

All medicines brought into hospital should be clearly identifiable (i.e. drug name clearly visible). If it is thought that the contents of a container or any loose substances are suspicious and then it should be treated as a suspected illegal substance.
An incident report must be submitted for all situations involving suspected or proven illegal substances found on Trust premises.
A suspected illegal substance may be those drugs suspected of being obtained illegally. Regardless of their legal class, these items must be treated as a controlled drug within the Trust.

“A substance refers to a chemical (psychoactive) agent that is used intentionally to alter mood and/or behaviour, or any prescribed medication, poison, toxin, alcohol, industrial solvent or other agents to which one may be exposed and
whose effects on the nervous system may lead to behavioural or cognitive disturbances.” (Psychiatric Dictionary 7th edition).
Where known that the patient has possession of a suspected illegal substance (including class A drugs)
35.7.1 The registered nurse/midwife in charge must take immediate action to obtain the substance, whilst maintaining safety of their staff.
