35.7.2 The registered nurse/midwife in charge should ask the patient to surrender any substances to them for safe and secure storage in a controlled drugs cupboard pending disposal. It may be considered appropriate to notify the LSMS/security manager at this point in time. They can be contacted via switchboard, 24/7.

35.7.3 If a patient is unconscious or is unable to voluntarily hand over the substance it should be removed without consent. The removal must be witnessed (i.e. registered member of staff or exceptionally the department manager). At a clinically appropriate time, the patient should be informed that a suspected illegal substance was found and removed.
35.7.4 The procedure in appendix  of this policy must be followed on removal of the substance, which includes recording in the patient's own and TTA CD register and informing pharmacy.
35.7.5 All actions taken should be clearly documented within the patients' health record:
Where appropriate, the patient should be offered a referral to Community Drug and Alcohol Services in line with the appropriate Trust protocols and care pathways.

Pharmacy staff will involve the CDAO and LSMS (Local Security Management Specialist), as appropriate. They will determine if the substance obtained requires notification to the police, and not the ward/department involved.
Action required if the patient refuses to hand over a suspected illegal substance
35.8.1 If it is suspected that a criminal act is being committed, then the patient should be informed that the police will be called and that their identity may be disclosed.
35.8.2 Under no circumstances should any agreement be reached whereby the patient will receive controlled drug substitutes for surrendering illegal substances.

35.8.3 Actions to ensure the removal of a suspected illegal substance from a patient should not delay any essential treatment for that individual. The only exception to this is where there is a risk of injury to Trust staff.
35.8.4 If, following this advice the patient refuses to hand over the substance/s Trust security must be called to attend. The security team will manage the situation in

accordance with the Trust policy and remain in attendance until the police arrive, if required. In an in-patient setting, if the patient expresses a desire to self-discharge at this point in time, then medical staff should be informed immediately.

35.8.5 If a search is undertaken by police it may be helpful for a member of registered staff of the same gender as the patient to accompany the police officer. The police can only search same-sex so for this type of incident a double-crewed unit would usually attend. It is important to maintain the privacy and the dignity of the patient throughout the search.
35.8.6 It is the responsibility of the police to lead the investigation and decide upon the outcome in these cases.

35.8.7 If police are asked to intervene and provide assistance, the patient's name and date of birth (if known) will be given to them along with the reasons for suspecting the presence of suspected illegal drugs. Pertinent information in relation to the clinical details of the patient must only be given if they have a direct bearing upon the need for a search to be undertaken.
35.8.8 All actions must be fully recorded in the patient's health record, including reasons for informing the police.

35.8.9 If the police are called, the police may obtain the suspected illegal substance or remove it and hand over to the nurse/midwife-in-charge. Where surrendered to the nurse/midwife-in-charge, appendix  must be followed.
35.8.10 Staff should be made aware that they might be asked to make a witness statement to the police in order to maintain the continuity of evidence.
Where known that other non-patient persons has possession of a suspected illegal substance (including class A drugs)
35.9.1 This includes visitors, contractors, volunteers with any suspicion of possessing, using or distributing illegal substances on the premises.

35.9.2 The registered nurse/midwife in charge must immediately contact the security team to attend the ward/department. The security team will manage the situation in accordance with the Violence and Antisocial Behaviour policy (or equivalent).

35.9.3 If it is suspected that a member of staff is in possession of an illegal substance, the Drug, Alcohol and Substance Misuse policy (or equivalent), will be followed. If the staff member is found to be in possession an illegal substance it will be removed from them and treated as described in this policy to ensure safe and secure custody of the substance prior to any further investigation.
Authority to Prescribe CDs
Medical Prescribers who have achieved full registration with the GMC are permitted to prescribe CDs for inpatient, outpatient and for discharge (TTA).

Doctors and dentists (excluding students) may prescribe all CDs. A license from the Home Office is required to prescribe Controlled Drugs for the treatment of addiction. Controlled Drugs may however be prescribed to an addicted person for the treatment of organic disease or injury
Medical doctors who are provisionally registered with the GMC (FY1) are only permitted to prescribe CDs for inpatient use on the drug chart or for Trust approved discharge prescriptions.
FY1s are not permitted to prescribe for outpatients or privately.
Non-medical independent prescribers must be registered as such with their professional body and be authorised by the Trust (as per Non-medical prescribing policy, or equivalent).
There are legal restrictions to the prescribing of CDs by non-medical independent prescribers, and the prescriber must prescribe within their competence.
Supplementary prescribers can prescribe any medicine (including CDs) as agreed by the patient and the doctor as part of the patient specific clinical management plan.
Principles of Prescribing CDs
It is the responsibility of the individual prescriber to ensure and maintain their own competency to prescribe medicines, and know any legal prescribing restrictions related to their registration.
All Trust authorised prescribers are only permitted to prescribe medicines included on the Trust formulary, for the indications stated (where appropriate).
Trust prescribers cannot prescribe for self, relatives or close friends.
Prescribers must not expect pharmacists to dispense illegal or invalid prescriptions.
All prescribers must be prepared to discuss the prescribing decision with other health professionals if further information is requested about the prescription.
When prescribing CDs, prescribers should take into account:
the benefits of controlled drug treatment;
the risks of prescribing, including dependency, overdose and diversion;
all prescribed and non-prescribed medicines the person is taking (particularly any centrally acting agents) and whether the person may be opioid naïve;
evidence-based sources, including Trust guidance, BNF and NICE, for prescribing decisions when possible.
For each prescribed CD, the prescriber should:

document clearly the indication and regimen for the controlled drug in the person's care record. This includes documenting a clear follow-up plan to the GP on clinic letters (for outpatients) and on discharge letters (for TTAs);
check the person's current clinical needs and, if appropriate, adjust the dose until a good balance is achieved between benefits and harms;
discuss with the patient the arrangements for reviewing and monitoring treatment.
When documenting and giving information to the patient (or carer administering) the prescriber should explain:
how long the person is expected to use the drug;
how long it will take to work;
what it has been prescribed for;
how to use controlled drugs when sustained-release and immediate- release formulations are prescribed together;
how it may affect the person's ability to drive (see the advice from the Department of Transport on drug driving and medicine: advice for healthcare professionals);
that it is to be used only by the person it is prescribed for.
When prescribing ‘when required' CDs the prescriber should:
document clear instructions for when and how to take or use the drug in the person's care record (i.e. clinic letter, discharge summary);
include dosage instructions on the prescription (with the maximum daily amount or frequency of doses) so that this can be included on the label when dispensed;
ask about and take into account any existing supplies the person has of ‘when required' controlled drugs.
When prescribing, reviewing or changing controlled drug prescriptions, prescribers should follow local (where available) or national guidelines and take into account the:
appropriate route;
dose (including when dose conversions or dose equivalence are needed);
formulation (including changes to formulations);
The Trust opioid equivalent dose conversion chart (or site equivalent) should be consulted.
If guidance on prescribing is not followed, the reasons why should be documented in the person's care record, and transferred to clinic/discharge letters as appropriate.
Prescribing for inpatients
Controlled Drugs must be written either on the Trust ePrescribing system or on an inpatient drug chart using indelible ink which cannot be erased.

The prescriber must ensure that the following information is specified. Some of these are pre-fixed within ePrescribing but must always be checked to ensure the correct selection has been made and customised to the specific patient:
Patient name, hospital number and NHS number is present on the front/top of chart;
Drug name, using the recommended International Non- Proprietary Name (rINN);
Formulation (e.g. liquid, slow release tablet etc.) Avoid prescribing brand names as these can change and the Trust may supply a different brand to the one patient has in community;
Dose, in weight units. Never write as a volume because strengths can vary;

A single route of administration. Where different routes are required, prescribe each as a separate item and clearly state when each should be used to avoid administration errors. Never prescribe CDs as IV/PO, or similar;
Strength, where applicable;
Frequency. For drugs that are non-daily administration (e.g. every 3 days) must have the days for administration clearly marked. Non- administering days must be crossed out using an ‘X';
Where the drug is prescribed ‘as required', a direction on a minimum interval for administration, and a maximum daily dose. For ePrescribing this should be entered as an ‘administration note';
A start date, (and a finish date, where appropriate);
The prescription must be signed.

Where a drug is prescribed for continuous infusion (i.e. subcutaneous syringe pump), the designated site syringe pump chart must be used. The main drug chart must be annotated that a syringe pump chart is in use. On ePrescribing ‘Chart S' should be prescribed.
Prescribing for Discharge (TTA) and Outpatients
All prescriptions must only be written on the Trust ePrescribing system/s or the approved prescription stationary.
It is legal for the prescription not to be written in the prescriber's own handwriting, however the prescriber signature must be handwritten, and any manual amendments countersigned.

To facilitate this within JAC/WellSky ePrescribing, a separate designated ‘CD prescription form' must be completed and submitted with the electronic prescription. Prescriptions without this form will not be accepted and pharmacy cannot supply the medicines.
For paper-based prescriptions (printed out, as needed) these must be signed by the prescriber with their usual signature and name printed in indelible ink.
All prescriptions for CDs are valid for 28 days from the date of the prescription. After this time they cannot be dispensed so would have to be re-written.
The Prescriber must ensure the patient's name and address and hospital number are recorded on the prescription and all particulars listed under section 39.2.
In addition the following is required:
Total quantity for pharmacy to supply written in both words and figures. This should be written as number of dose units (tablets, ampoules etc.);
The total quantity for liquid preparations should be the volume required (e.g. 100ml);
If different tablets are required, quantities for each strength must be listed in words and figures;
Date;
The signature and printed name of the prescriber;
A bleep/contact number so they can be contacted for queries, if needed.
Maximum quantities of schedule 2, 3 and 4 CDs should not exceed 30 days.

In exceptional circumstances, where there is clinical justification to exceed  days requirement the reason must be recorded in the patient's clinical records and the prescription. Pharmacists must have a clinical justification in order to dispense a prescription that exceeds  days' supply.
Pharmacy dispensing of CD TTA/Outpatient Prescriptions

39.10.1 The pharmacy department must not dispense CDs on prescriptions that do not comply with legal requirements. Pharmacy staff must contact the prescriber issuing incomplete CD prescriptions to request completion of details that are legally required.
39.10.2 Pharmacy staff must refer to the current published ‘Medicines, Ethics and Practice' guide for prescribing support queries.

39.10.3 Registered pharmacy staff must see the original prescription, not just a copy, before the TTA is supplied from the pharmacy department. The pharmacy can start to dispense a CD TTA from a copy (i.e. electronically scanned) but the original must be seen before the final prescription can be released.
Pharmacist amendments to prescriptions

39.11.1 The only errors that registered pharmacists can amend are minor typographical errors or spelling mistakes. They are permitted to add the total quantity of the preparation of the CD where it is specified in either words or figures but not both.
39.11.2 A pharmacist may make certain amendments to Schedule 2 and 3 CD prescriptions provided that:
having exercised all due diligence, the pharmacist is satisfied on reasonable grounds that the prescription is genuine;

39.11.3 Having exercised all due diligence, the pharmacist is satisfied on reasonable grounds that they are supplying the CD in accordance with the intention of the prescriber. All corrective amendments made by registered pharmacists will be in ink or otherwise indelibly (i.e. electronically). The prescription will be marked to make clear the amendment they have made is attributable to them (amended electronically or for paper prescriptions, sign name and date amendment).
CDs within a PGD
All procedures developed for the use of CDs in PGDs must comply with the Misuse of Drugs Regulations in addition to PGD legislation and national guidance on PGDs.

The inclusion of CDs within a PGD is limited and is restricted by law. For further details please refer to the Policy for the development, approval and implementation of Patient Group Directions (PGDs) (MSEPO-20210).
Clinical Trials involving CD Investigational Medicinal Products

All CD's supplied as Investigational Medicinal Products (IMP) as part of a clinical trial must be done so in accordance with the Misuse of Drugs Regulations (1971) in addition to the Medicines for Human Use (Clinical Trials) Regulations 2004 and subsequent amendments.
Please refer to the Policy on the Safe Handling, Effective Use and Management of Investigational Medicinal Products (MSEPO-20204).

For trials that involve the use of Schedule 1 CDs, such as cannabinoids, a licence from the Home Office must be obtained before the item is received into stock or supplied. The licence will be held by the Director of Pharmacy. A copy of the licence is to be kept with the trial protocol.
For double blind trials where it is not known if the IMP is active drug or placebo, the IMP should be handled as if it were a CD whilst it remains on site.
Within the pharmacy, and if stored on wards, clinical trial CDs must be clearly segregated from routine CD stock.

Clinical trial CD IMP activity (receipt, supply and destruction) must be entered into the CD register using a page specifically for the trial CD. In addition to this, separate accountability logs may be required by the trial sponsor and these will be stored in the pharmacy site file (PSF) for the trial.

Discrepancies must be managed as for all other CDs. A record of any investigation should be kept in the pharmacy site file for the specific trial. The sponsor of the clinical trial and principal investigator should be informed of any discrepancies in accordance with usual trial management requirements.

Returned/expired/surplus IMP at end of study must be stored in a separate ‘quarantine' area of the CD cupboard. The pharmacy summary form for each trial will detail the trial specific procedures for destruction of patient returned/expired/end of study surplus IMP. Drug accountability records should be completed promptly on return of any CD IMP.
Authorisation for destruction of CD IMPs must be received by the trial sponsor prior to destruction. This authorisation must be placed in the PSF.

Destruction of CD IMPs must be booked into the CD destruction register as per standard practice. CD IMP's will be destroyed in the same way as other CDs. A drug destruction certificate must be completed.

Supply of CD IMP from the Trust pharmacy departments to the research department or other third party organisation, will follow the same governance arrangements for safe use as for elsewhere in the organisation.
All activities should be covered by SOPs and processes should be robust and auditable.
Managing CDs in Operating Theatres
The registered nurse, midwife or ODP in charge of an operating theatre or theatre suite is responsible for the safe and appropriate management of all CDs.

The registered nurse, midwife or ODP in charge can delegate control of access (i.e. key-holding) of the CD cupboard to another, such as a registered nurse, ODP (or registered radiographer if brachytherapy theatre).

A registered nurse, midwife or ODP may remove CDs from the cupboard and/or return them to the cupboard only on the specific authority of the registered nurse, midwife or ODP in charge or doctor. However, legal responsibility remains with the registered nurse, midwife or ODP in charge. Whilst the task can be delegated, the responsibility cannot. The person to whom the task has been delegated is still professionally accountable for his/her actions. The same conditions apply to order and stock checking of CDs.

Any written operating procedures for the management of CDs in in-house operating theatres and recovery wards should be up-to-date and all staff, including anaesthetists, should be aware of them. Procedures are finalised only after a period of consultation to ensure ownership and practicality within the confines of compliance with legal requirements and national Guidance. All procedures must be discussed with and approved by the CDAO to be valid.
The storage arrangement for CDs in Theatres will conform to the general requirements for security and storage of CDs on wards and departments.
Separate stocks of controlled drugs shall be kept in each anaesthetic room and the recovery room.
A separate CD register is kept for each anaesthetic room and recovery room and stock must not be transferred from one room to another.
Each Theatre suite must have a clear procedure for their key holding. At the end of the theatre list all CD keys must be returned to the registered nurse/midwife in charge.
Stock checking should occur on the receipt of the CD keys prior to the start of each theatre list as a minimum frequency.
Stock checks must be performed by the designated key holder and a second registered nurse, midwife, ODP or other authorised competency-trained practitioner approved by the CDAO.

When CDs are delivered to a theatre or theatre suite, the pharmacy delivery person will ensure that all CD deliveries are received in person by an authorised theatre staff member. The signatory is responsible for distributing the CDs to the various locations within the respective theatre suite. On no account should CDs be left unattended. Receipt of CDs in theatres must follow this policy.
Prescribing of CDs

The anaesthetist on duty is usually responsible for prescribing CDs but other prescribers may also be involved. Nurse independent prescribers may also be responsible for prescribing or administration of diamorphine or morphine for post-operative pain. Prescribing of CDs will follow the general provisions for prescribing of CDs for inpatients (see section X).
Administration of CDs

42.14.1 A record of administration should be made on the appropriate chart immediately after administration by the person who administered the CD. This should include the date, the identity of the person, the dose administered and the time of administration.

42.14.2 The practice of issuing “active stock” to the anaesthetist then returning the unused portion to stock, recording both issues and returns in the theatre CD record book should be avoided. An amount should be issued to the anaesthetist for a specific patient and any surplus drug should be destroyed and witnessed. Any surplus drug should be rendered irretrievable as per this policy.

42.14.3 When a dose of a controlled drug is administered to a patient in the absence of a registered nurse, midwife or ODP, the appropriate entry in the CD register must be made by the anaesthetist to confirm what has been administered.

42.14.4 Injectables should be treated as intended for single use only unless the label specifically states that they are licensed for multiple uses or to provide more than a single dose on any one occasion.

42.14.5 A partially used syringe containing a controlled drug, labelled with the drug name and strength, may accompany a patient from the theatre to the recovery room and be handed to the registered nurse responsible for the patient's care. Any remaining drug shall be destroyed before the patient leaves the recovery room and the destruction recorded and witnessed by the registered nurse and the anaesthetist, or another authorised witness.
Managing CDs in Midwifery Practice

Registered midwives have provisions in law to possess and administer diamorphine, morphine, pethidine and pentazocine; provided it is in the course of their professional practice (known as midwives exemptions).

They may legally do so without the need for a prescription or patient-specific direction (PSD) from a medical practitioner. Provided the requirements of any conditions attached to those exemptions are met, a patient group direction (PGD) is not required. If a medicine is not included in the midwives exemptions then a PGD, or a prescription, or a patient-specific written direction is required. These exemptions are regularly reviewed and the latest information will be provided by the department of midwifery. The supervisor or midwives is responsible for ensuring all midwives adhere to the most up-to-date legislation. Midwives should consult relevant Midwifery procedures for further details.

However, the Trust does not support the possession and storage of controlled drugs by midwives in community (i.e. vehicles or a midwife's home). This includes transporting between locations. This is on the grounds of personal safety of the community midwife team and was found to be a significant security risk. Where a controlled drug is desired for home birth by a mother, the community midwife will either:
Request that a supply of the controlled drugs is obtained by the mother from their GP, and remains at the home of the mother or;
Recommend a Maternity Unit Birth.

The mother's GP should supply the appropriate prescription and this should be dispensed at a local community pharmacy, ahead of time. Controlled drugs obtained by a woman by prescription from her doctor, for use in her home confinement, are her own property and are not the midwife's responsibility.

Midwives must record full details of CDs administered in their own CD register, requirements as outlined in this policy. This register should be used solely for that purpose and be made available for inspection as required by the supervisor of midwives. The requirement for an authorised witness for the administration of Pethidine is not required. The patient should act as the witness and sign the administration record and register accordingly.
Any schedule 2 CD prepared or drawn up but no longer required or no longer usable, must be destroyed by the midwife and documented in the register; in accordance with this policy.

If any of the CD is unused then advice should be given to the mother or another family member about this being returned to the community pharmacy for destruction. This should be returned as soon as possible and ideally to the pharmacy from where the medicine was originally dispensed.

Occasionally midwives may consider that the home circumstances mean that leaving the CD with the mother or family for destruction is inappropriate. Usually this would result from the midwife having concerns that the CD would not be returned for destruction and could be diverted either for personal use or sale. In such rare cases the midwife must use their professional discretion and may remove the CD from the home as long as the mother gives her permission. The CD must be bought back to the supplying site hospital pharmacy and signed into the patient's own CD destruction register. The midwife should contact the dispensary in advance and speak to the dispensary manager, or deputy, to

arrange a mutually convenient time for this to happen. The community midwife should notify their supervisor that they have returned CDs to pharmacy and make entry to this effect in their midwifery records.
Managing Patches in Diagnostic imaging departments
Occasionally medicated patches can interfere with some diagnostic imaging procedures. Common patches in use are controlled drugs.
The removal of medicated patches for scans should only be done if absolutely necessary as this can affect pain control.
Radiology staff will identify if there is a need, depending on type of scan and location of the patch (as per their departmental procedure).

The plan will be discussed with radiology staff and the registered nurse caring for the patient (or patient themselves for outpatients) and be documented on the radiology patient record. For outpatients this should be documented on any letters issued to the patient. Outpatients should be requested to ensure they have a replacement patch at home to reapply of removal is necessary.
It is preferable for the patient to remove their patch or the registered nurse (if inpatient) prior to being sent for a scan.
If this is not done, radiology staff removing patches will document the following:
Who removed the patch (if a radiographer);
Time the drug patch was removed if removed by a radiographer;
The name of the ward registered staff member who agreed the arrangements.
Patches must be disposed of in line with this policy.

Where there is a need to remove a patch then the registered nurse will ensure a replacement patch is available for the patient when they return to the ward. This will need prescribing or existing prescription changed by prescriber as appropriate to allow administration. The rationale will be clearly documented in the patient health record.
Managing CDs in Pharmacy departments

The site Pharmacy Operations Manager is responsible for management of CDs in the site Pharmacy department. Day-to-day management of CDs, e.g. receipt and issue of dispensary stock, is delegated to registered pharmacists or competency-trained pharmacy technicians and pharmacy assistants; in line with pharmacy departmental SOPs.
Under the Home Office Controlled Drugs Licence the Site Pharmacy Head of Department is the person responsible for the security of the premises licensed.
Overall legal responsibility for CDs remains with the Chief Pharmacist, as the Trust CDAO and the ‘person in charge' named on the Home Office Controlled Drugs Licence.
Ordering CDs into the Trust

45.4.1  The ordering of CDs from SUH suppliers, wholesalers and manufacturers and receipt of CDs follows the principles of good procurement. This is in accordance with MSEPO-20203 Pharmacy Procurement of Medicines Policy and departmental SOPs.
Receipt of CDs into the Trust
45.5.1 Controlled Drugs received into the Trust have additional checks undertaken by pharmacy staff to ensure exact quantity is received at point of receipt; as per departmental SOPs.

45.5.2 All received CDs are recorded into the legal site premises pharmacy CD register. Recording of receipt will be undertaken immediately on day of receipt, and in any event no later than 24 hours after receipt.
Storage within Pharmacy

45.6.1 CD Stock is immediately put away into the appropriate section of the site pharmacy CDs cupboard. This is segregated into high strength and low strength following same principles as this policy.

45.6.2 The Pharmacy CDs cupboard/Room complies with the Misuse of Drugs (Safe Custody) Regulations. Depending on site this is either using CD-compliant metal CD cupboards or within a designated room with approved security features (e.g. reinforced wall).
Issuing of CDs to Wards and Departments

45.7.1  Pharmacy CD SOPs cover all stages of the management of medicines by the directorate. This includes issuing of CDs against valid orders from clinical areas, labelling, and appropriate archiving of CD documentation.
Record Keeping
45.8.1 Each site pharmacy dispensary maintains the Trust legal controlled drug register. All dispensaries utilise a designated CD register for the purposes of running a hospital pharmacy.

45.8.2 Register entries are always made in consecutive, chronological order, in ink or otherwise indelible. All entries are made on the day of receipt or supply. All errors are corrected using the same process as outlined in this policy.
45.8.3 The following staff may complete a Pharmacy CDs Register:
A registered pharmacist employed by the Trust;
Any CD-trained registered pharmacy technician, pharmacy dispensary assistant, pre-registration pharmacist or pre-registration pharmacy technician;
Pharmacy staff are authorised to handle CDs by the dispensary manager on behalf of the site Pharmacy Operations Manager;

Any person who is being trained by a competent member of pharmacy staff (see above), must be under their direct supervision. The supervisor must countersign each entry until they are signed off as competent.

45.8.4 Each drug, name, form and strength is recorded on different pages of the register. The drug, name form and strength are written in full at the top of each page. An index is kept at the front of the register.
45.8.5 For CDs received into stock the register entry will include:
The date received;
The name and address of the supplier, e.g. wholesaler or Drug Purchasing Centre;
Order/requisition number;
The quantity received;
The name form and strength of the Controlled Drug.
For CDs supplied the register entry will include:
Date on which the transaction was effected;
Name and address (of person or departments supplied);
Authority of person to be in possession (i.e. name of doctor or ward sister etc.);
Supplied by;
CD requisition reference number- if applicable (e.g. CD book order number);
Amount received into stock or supplied;
Balance in stock at end of transaction;
Person collecting Sch 2 CDPOM (Patient/ Patient's rep/Healthcare professional) and if Healthcare professional, name and address;
Designation of the person collecting;
Was proof of identity requested of patient/patients representative (Yes/No);
Was proof of identity of person collecting provided (Yes/No).
Stock Checks
45.10.1 The balance of all stock is checked and recorded as correct by the person making any new entry.

45.10.2 All CDs held as pharmacy stock must be checked monthly. A site designated Senior Technician for dispensary services is responsible for managing this process under authority of the site Pharmacy Operations Manager.

45.10.3 CDs stock checks are only carried out by authorised pharmacy persons and documented in the CD register in line with the departmental SOP. Discrepancies are managed in accordance with this policy.
Training Requirements
Medication training at induction must include explanation of Trust processes, and is delivered by the registrant in charge of the staff member involved.
Training materials are those provided by the appendices to this policy.
Face to face training sessions to support audit compliance is available adhoc from the site medication safety nurse, on request (BTUH site only).
Monitoring and Audit

The Trust CD audit is undertaken against the policy standards (appendix 13) and an action plan is received by the Ward manager (or equivalent) for each area and the Matron. Results are published as part of the Medication nursing dashboard issued by pharmacy.
Spot checks of all CDs management can be undertaken at any time and will be unannounced where possible.

Everyone has the duty of reporting any concerns they have about CDs either about the procedures in place or the actions of any colleagues in relation to CDs. This includes concerns that may negatively affect patient safety. Even small deviations from policy can indicate a much more serious underlying concern. All staff has a professional responsibility to report any concerns. Staff should consult a pharmacist in confidence or speak directly with the CDAO. Alternatively the Trust whistleblowing policy (or equivalent) can be followed. It must be appreciated that individuals could be subject to fitness to practice processes if misuse of CDs is occurring and warning signs have not been reported, where known.
AdiOS software monitoring of CD usage will include Schedules 4 and 5, to identify and take swift action on diversion; in addition to those schedules subject to legal control.

Appendix 12: Procedure dealing with suspected illegal drugs/ substances
If any substance is suspected to be illegal in nature, and is discovered or received by a staff member then the following steps must be followed.
Two registered permanent staff members should be involved throughout.
If the suspected illegal substance is associated with a particular patient, then a description of the substance and the associated circumstances should be recorded in the patient health record.

Under no circumstances should the substance be returned to the patient unless there is an immediate threat of violence and aggression towards the staff member and the safety of other patients/premises are at risk.
A description of the substance (do not assume any analysis has been conducted) e.g.: record "brown block" rather than "cannabis resin" (do not assume you know what it is);
A description of the quantity/amount (an approximation will be sufficient);
When it was found (time and date);
Where it was found (e.g. ‘received from a patient in AMU');
Patient identifiers MUST NOT appear on the package.

Stick a label on the package using a label used to seal the bag (so it is tamper evident). The senior manager on duty at the time of the incident as well as the registered witness will sign the label;
The label must remain intact throughout the audit chain from receipt, recording in register through to handing over to pharmacy (see step 5).
Enter into the Patients own and TTA CD Register as ‘Suspected Illegal Substance' and brief description e.g. ‘White powder', ‘brown resinous block';
Enter the page number from the CD register onto the package;
Place the intact package containing the substance in the patient's own section of the CD cupboard;
This is a temporary arrangement for security purposes whilst awaiting the Pharmacy.
During working hours a registered pharmacy staff member will attend.
Out of hours the Oncall Pharmacist will only attend where the substance is so large in size (i.e. huge bag) it cannot be secured in ward CD cupboard.

A registered pharmacy professional will sign out from the ward/deparment CD register and bring back to pharmacy as per the section 34 of this policy. They shall enter the substance into the ‘Suspected Illegal Substances' page in the pharmacy CD register.
The Pharmacy Operations Manager and CD Accountable Officer shall be notified at the earliest opportunity.
Where appropriate, pharmacy will contact the Police. Where a crime number is issued this is recorded in the pharmacy CD register.

Either the substance is signed out of the register into possession of the police (on their attendance to site) or agreement is reached with them for pharmacy to destroy on site in accordance with the Trust CD Policy.
(i.e. was for supply rather than personal use):
The CD Accountable Officer must be informed immediately by the registered pharmacy professional who takes the call from the ward/department concerned.
The CDAO will liaise with the Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) and inform the police.

Arrangement for transferring the substance/s to the police will be made. Where possible the police should collect from the Trust. However it is deemed lawful under the Misuse of Drugs Act for the LSMS to take possession of a suspected illegal substance for transportation to the police providing the police have been notified in advance of the intention to do this.
